en: CHAPTER I, THERE IS NO ONE LEFT
zh: 第一章，已经没有人了

en: When Mary Lennox was sent to Misselthwaite Manor to live with her uncle everybody said she was the most disagreeable-looking child ever seen.
zh: 当玛丽 · 伦诺克斯被送到 Misselthwaite Manor 和她叔叔一起生活时，每个人都说她是有史以来最难相处的孩子。

en: It was true, too.
zh: 这也是真的。

en: She had a little thin face and a little thin body, thin light hair and a sour expression.
zh: 她有一张瘦小的脸，一个瘦小的身体，稀疏的浅色头发和一个酸溜溜的表情。

en: Her hair was yellow, and her face was yellow because she had been born in India and had always been ill in one way or another.
zh: 她的头发是黄色的，她的脸是黄色的，因为她出生在印度，而且总是以这样或那样的方式生病。

en: Her father had held a position under the English Government and had always been busy and ill himself, and her mother had been a great beauty who cared only to go to parties and amuse herself with gay people.
zh: 她的父亲曾在英国政府任职，自己总是忙碌而且生病，而她的母亲是个大美，只关心参加聚会，和同性恋者一起消遣。

en: She had not wanted a little girl at all, and when Mary was born she handed her over to the care of an Ayah, who was made to understand that if she wished to please the Mem Sahib she must keep the child out of sight as much as possible.
zh: 她根本就不想要一个小女孩，玛丽出生的时候，她把她交给了一个叫阿雅的人照顾。阿雅被教导，如果她想取悦 Mem Sahib，就必须尽可能地把孩子藏起来。

en: So when she was a sickly, fretful, ugly little baby she was kept out of the way, and when she became a sickly, fretful, toddling thing she was kept out of the way also.
zh: 所以当她还是一个病怏怏、烦躁不安、丑陋不堪的小婴儿的时候，她被挡在了外面，当她变成一个病怏怏、烦躁不安、蹒跚学步的小东西的时候，她也被挡在了外面。

en: She never remembered seeing familiarly anything but the dark faces of her Ayah and the other native servants, and as they always obeyed her and gave her her own way in everything,
zh: 除了她的阿亚和其他本地仆人的黑脸，她从来不记得看到过什么熟悉的东西，因为他们总是服从她，在任何事情上都给她自己的方式,

en: because the Mem Sahib would be angry if she was disturbed by her crying, by the time she was six years old she was as tyrannical and selfish a little pig as ever lived.
zh: 因为如果她被自己的哭声打扰了，大人会很生气的，到她六岁的时候，她就变成了一个暴君，一个自私的小猪。

en: The young English governess who came to teach her to read and write disliked her so much that she gave up her place in three months,
zh: 那个来教她读书写字的年轻英国女家庭教师非常不喜欢她，以至于她在三个月内就放弃了她的工作,

en: and when other governesses came to try to fill it they always went away in a shorter time than the first one.
zh: 当其他家庭教师来填补空缺的时候，他们总是比第一个家庭教师离开的时间要短。

en: So if Mary had not chosen to really want to know how to read books she would never have learned her letters at all.
zh: 因此，如果玛丽没有选择真正想知道如何读书，她就根本不会学习她的书信。

en: One frightfully hot morning, when she was about nine years old, she awakened feeling very cross, and she became crosser still when she saw that the servant who stood by her bedside was not her Ayah.
zh: 在一个非常炎热的早晨，当她大约九岁的时候，她醒来时感到非常生气，当她看到站在她床边的仆人不是她的阿姨时，她更加生气了。

en: \"Why did you come?\" she said to the strange woman.
zh: “你为什么来?”她对那个奇怪的女人说。

en: \"I will not let you stay. Send my Ayah to me.\"
zh: “我不会让你留下的，把我的阿亚交给我”

en: The woman looked frightened, but she only stammered that the Ayah could not come and when Mary threw herself into a passion and beat and kicked her,
zh: 那个女人看起来很害怕，但是她只是结结巴巴地说阿雅不能来当玛丽全身心投入到一种激情中，打她，踢她的时候,

en: she looked only more frightened and repeated that it was not possible for the Ayah to come to Missie Sahib.
zh: 她看起来更害怕了，她反复说阿亚族人不可能来 Missie Sahib。

en: There was something mysterious in the air that morning.
zh: 那天早上空气中弥漫着神秘的气息。

en: Nothing was done in its regular order and several of the native servants seemed missing, while those whom Mary saw slunk or hurried about with ashy and scared faces.
zh: 一切都没有按照正常的顺序进行，好几个当地的仆人似乎失踪了，而玛丽看到的那些人或是偷偷摸摸的，或是满脸灰色、惊慌失措的，匆匆忙忙地走来走去。

en: But no one would tell her anything and her Ayah did not come.
zh: 但是没有人告诉她任何事情，她的阿亚也没有来。

en: She was actually left alone as the morning went on, and at last she wandered out into the garden and began to play by herself under a tree near the veranda.
zh: 随着早晨的过去，她实际上是一个人，最后她走进花园，开始独自在阳台附近的一棵树下玩耍。

en: She pretended that she was making a flower-bed, and she stuck big scarlet hibiscus blossoms into little heaps of earth,
zh: 她假装在做一个花坛，把鲜红色的大芙蓉花插在一小堆土里,

en: all the time growing more and more angry and muttering to herself the things she would say and the names she would call Saidie when she returned.
zh: 一直以来，她变得越来越生气，喃喃自语着她要说的话，以及她回来后要叫赛迪的名字。

en: \"Pig! Pig! Daughter of Pigs!\" she said, because to call a native a pig is the worst insult of all.
zh: “猪! 猪! 猪的女儿!”她说，因为把当地人叫做猪是最大的侮辱。

en: She was grinding her teeth and saying this over and over again when she heard her mother come out on the veranda with some one.
zh: 她咬着牙，一遍又一遍地说着这句话，这时她听到她妈妈和一个人从阳台上走了出来。

en: She was with a fair young man and they stood talking together in low strange voices.
zh: 她和一个漂亮的年轻人在一起，他们站在一起用奇怪的低声说话。

en: Mary knew the fair young man who looked like a boy.
zh: 玛丽认识那个长得像男孩的漂亮年轻人。

en: She had heard that he was a very young officer who had just come from England.
zh: 她听说他是一个刚从英国来的年轻军官。

en: The child stared at him, but she stared most at her mother.
zh: 孩子盯着他，但她最多的是盯着她的母亲。

en: She always did this when she had a chance to see her, because the Mem Sahib, Mary used to call her that oftener than anything else, was such a tall, slim, pretty person and wore such lovely clothes.
zh: 她总是在有机会见到她的时候这样做，因为玛丽以前经常这样称呼她，她是一个高挑、苗条、漂亮的人，穿着非常可爱的衣服。

en: Her hair was like curly silk and she had a delicate little nose which seemed to be disdaining things, and she had large laughing eyes.
zh: 她的头发像卷曲的丝绸，她有一个精致的小鼻子，似乎是轻蔑的东西，她有大笑的眼睛。

en: All her clothes were thin and floating, and Mary said they were \"full of lace.\" They looked fuller of lace than ever this morning, but her eyes were not laughing at all.
zh: 她所有的衣服都又薄又漂浮，玛丽说它们“充满了蕾丝。”。今天早上，它们看起来比以往任何时候都更有花边了，但是她的眼睛一点也没有笑。

en: They were large and scared and lifted imploringly to the fair boy officer's face.
zh: 它们又大又吓人，哀求地举到那个漂亮的男孩军官面前。

en: \"Is it so very bad? Oh, is it?\" Mary heard her say.
zh: “有那么糟糕吗? 哦，是吗?”玛丽听到她说。

en: \"Awfully,\" the young man answered in a trembling voice.
zh: “太可怕了,”年轻人用颤抖的声音回答。

en: \"Awfully, Mrs. Lennox. You ought to have gone to the hills two weeks ago.\" The Mem Sahib wrung her hands.
zh: “太糟糕了，伦诺克斯太太。你两个星期前就应该上山去了。”议员扭着她的手说。

en: \"Oh, I know I ought!\" she cried. \"I only stayed to go to that silly dinner party.
zh: “哦，我知道我应该去!”她喊道，“我留下来只是为了参加那个愚蠢的晚宴。

en: What a fool I was!\" At that very moment such a loud sound of wailing broke out from the servants' quarters that she clutched the young man's arm, and Mary stood shivering from head to foot.
zh: 我真是个傻瓜！就在这时，仆人的房间里突然传来一阵巨大的哭声，玛丽紧紧抓住那个年轻人的胳膊，浑身颤抖地站在那里。

en: The wailing grew wilder and wilder.
zh: 哭声越来越大。

en: \"What is it? What is it?\" Mrs. Lennox gasped.
zh: “怎么了? 怎么了?”伦诺克斯太太倒抽了一口冷气。

en: \"Some one has died,\" answered the boy officer.
zh: “有人死了,”少年军官回答。

en: \"You did not say it had broken out among your servants.\"
zh: “你没有说是在你的仆人中间发生的。”

en: \"I did not know!\" the Mem Sahib cried.
zh: “我不知道!”大人喊道。

en: \"Come with me! Come with me!\" and she turned and ran into the house.
zh: “跟我来! 跟我来!”她转身跑进屋里。

en: After that appalling things happened, and the mysteriousness of the morning was explained to Mary.
zh: 在那之后，可怕的事情发生了，那天早晨的神秘事件被向玛丽解释了。

en: The cholera had broken out in its most fatal form and people were dying like flies.
zh: 霍乱以其最致命的形式爆发了，人们像苍蝇一样死去。

en: The Ayah had been taken ill in the night, and it was because she had just died that the servants had wailed in the huts.
zh: 阿雅在夜里生病了，正是因为她刚刚死去，仆人们才在小屋里哀号。

en: Before the next day three other servants were dead and others had run away in terror.
zh: 第二天以前，又有三个仆人死了，其他人惊恐地逃走了。

en: There was panic on every side, and dying people in all the bungalows.
zh: 到处都是恐慌，所有的平房里都是垂死的人。

en: During the confusion and bewilderment of the second day Mary hid herself in the nursery and was forgotten by every one.
zh: 在第二天的混乱和困惑中，玛丽躲在育儿室里，被每个人都忘记了。

en: Nobody thought of her, nobody wanted her, and strange things happened of which she knew nothing.
zh: 没有人想起她，没有人想要她，奇怪的事情发生了，而她对此一无所知。

en: Mary alternately cried and slept through the hours.
zh: 玛丽时而哭，时而睡。

en: She only knew that people were ill and that she heard mysterious and frightening sounds.
zh: 她只知道人们生病了，她听到了神秘而可怕的声音。

en: Once she crept into the dining-room and found it empty, though a partly finished meal was on the table and chairs and plates looked as if they had been hastily pushed back when the diners rose suddenly for some reason.
zh: 她蹑手蹑脚地走进餐厅，发现里面空无一人，尽管桌子上有一顿吃了一半的饭，椅子和盘子看起来好像被匆忙地推回去了，因为食客们不知道为什么突然站起来了。

en: The child ate some fruit and biscuits, and being thirsty she drank a glass of wine which stood nearly filled.
zh: 孩子吃了一些水果和饼干，口渴的时候，她喝了一杯几乎满了的葡萄酒。

en: It was sweet, and she did not know how strong it was.
zh: 这是甜的，她不知道它是多么强大。

en: Very soon it made her intensely drowsy, and she went back to her nursery and shut herself in again, frightened by cries she heard in the huts and by the hurrying sound of feet.
zh: 很快，这使她昏昏欲睡，她回到育儿室，又把自己关在里面，害怕听到小屋里的哭声和急促的脚步声。

en: The wine made her so sleepy that she could scarcely keep her eyes open and she lay down on her bed and knew nothing more for a long time.
zh: 酒让她昏昏欲睡，几乎睁不开眼睛，她躺在床上，很长一段时间什么也不知道。

en: Many things happened during the hours in which she slept so heavily, but she was not disturbed by the wails and the sound of things being carried in and out of the bungalow.
zh: 在她睡得那么沉的几个小时里发生了很多事情，但是她没有被哭声和东西进出平房的声音所打扰。

en: When she awakened she lay and stared at the wall. The house was perfectly still. She had never known it to be so silent before.
zh: 当她醒来时，她躺在那里，盯着墙壁。房子一点动静都没有。她以前从来不知道这里这么安静。

en: She heard neither voices nor footsteps, and wondered if everybody had got well of the cholera and all the trouble was over.
zh: 她既听不到声音也听不到脚步声，不知道是否每个人都从霍乱中康复了，所有的麻烦都结束了。

en: She wondered also who would take care of her now her Ayah was dead.
zh: 她也想知道现在她的阿亚死了，谁来照顾她。

en: There would be a new Ayah, and perhaps she would know some new stories.
zh: 会有一个新的阿雅，也许她会知道一些新的故事。

en: Mary had been rather tired of the old ones.
zh: 玛丽对那些旧的已经相当厌倦了。

en: She did not cry because her nurse had died.
zh: 她没有哭，因为她的护士死了。

en: She was not an affectionate child and had never cared much for any one.
zh: 她不是一个多情的孩子，从来没有关心过任何人。

en: The noise and hurrying about and wailing over the cholera had frightened her, and she had been angry because no one seemed to remember that she was alive.
zh: 霍乱带来的噪音、匆忙和哀号把她吓坏了，她很生气，因为似乎没有人记得她还活着。

en: Every one was too panic-stricken to think of a little girl no one was fond of.
zh: 每个人都惊慌失措，想不起一个没有人喜欢的小女孩。

en: When people had the cholera it seemed that they remembered nothing but themselves.
zh: 当人们患上霍乱时，他们似乎只记得自己。

en: But if every one had got well again, surely some one would remember and come to look for her.
zh: 但是如果每个人都康复了，肯定会有人记得并来找她的。

en: But no one came, and as she lay waiting the house seemed to grow more and more silent.
zh: 但是没有人来，当她躺着等待的时候，屋子里似乎变得越来越安静。

en: She heard something rustling on the matting and when she looked down she saw a little snake gliding along and watching her with eyes like jewels.
zh: 她听到席子上有什么东西在沙沙作响，当她向下看时，她看到一条小蛇在滑行，用宝石般的眼睛看着她。

en: She was not frightened, because he was a harmless little thing who would not hurt her and he seemed in a hurry to get out of the room.
zh: 她并不害怕，因为他是一个不会伤害她的无害的小东西，而且他看起来急于离开房间。

en: He slipped under the door as she watched him.
zh: 她注视着他，他从门缝里钻了进去。

en: \"How queer and quiet it is,\" she said.
zh: “多么奇怪和安静啊,”她说。

en: \"It sounds as if there was no one in the bungalow but me and the snake.\" Almost the next minute she heard footsteps in the compound, and then on the veranda.
zh: “听起来平房里除了我和蛇就没有别人了。几乎下一分钟，她就听到了院子里的脚步声，然后是走廊上的脚步声。

en: They were men's footsteps, and the men entered the bungalow and talked in low voices.
zh: 那是男人的脚步声，男人们走进平房，低声交谈着。

en: No one went to meet or speak to them and they seemed to open doors and look into rooms.
zh: 没有人去见他们，也没有人和他们说话，他们似乎打开门，向房间里张望。

en: \"What desolation!\" she heard one voice say.
zh: “多么荒凉!”她听到一个声音说。

en: \"That pretty, pretty woman! I suppose the child, too.
zh: “那个漂亮，漂亮的女人! 我想那个孩子也是。

en: I heard there was a child, though no one ever saw her.\" Mary was standing in the middle of the nursery when they opened the door a few minutes later.
zh: 我听说有个孩子，但没人见过她。几分钟后，当他们打开门时，玛丽正站在育儿室的中央。

en: She looked an ugly, cross little thing and was frowning because she was beginning to be hungry and feel disgracefully neglected.
zh: 她看起来是一个丑陋的、脾气暴躁的小东西，正皱着眉头，因为她开始觉得饿了，觉得自己被忽视了。

en: The first man who came in was a large officer she had once seen talking to her father.
zh: 第一个走进来的是一个大个子军官，她曾经见过他和她父亲说话。

en: He looked tired and troubled, but when he saw her he was so startled that he almost jumped back.
zh: 他看上去疲惫不堪，忧心忡忡，但当他看到她时，他吓了一跳，差点跳了回去。

en: \"Barney!\" he cried out.
zh: “巴尼!”他喊道。

en: \"There is a child here! A child alone! In a place like this! Mercy on us, who is she!\" \"I am Mary Lennox,\" the little girl said, drawing herself up stiffly.
zh: “这里有个孩子！一个孩子！在这种地方！饶了我们吧，她是谁！“我是玛丽 · 伦诺克斯,”小女孩说着，僵硬地站了起来。

en: She thought the man was very rude to call her father's bungalow \"A place like this!\" \"I fell asleep when every one had the cholera and I have only just wakened up.
zh: 她认为这个男人把她父亲的平房叫做“这样的地方！”当每个人都得了霍乱的时候我睡着了，而我才刚刚醒来。

en: Why does nobody come?\" \"It is the child no one ever saw!\" exclaimed the man, turning to his companions.
zh: 为什么没有人来?”“是那个从来没有人见过的孩子!”那个男人叫道，转向他的同伴。

en: \"She has actually been forgotten!\" \"Why was I forgotten?\" Mary said, stamping her foot.
zh: “她实际上已经被遗忘了!”“为什么我被遗忘了?”玛丽跺着脚说。

en: \"Why does nobody come?\" The young man whose name was Barney looked at her very sadly.
zh: “为什么没有人来?”那个叫巴尼的年轻人非常伤心地看着她。

en: Mary even thought she saw him wink his eyes as if to wink tears away.
zh: 玛丽甚至认为她看见他眨眼睛，好像是要眨眼把眼泪带走。

en: \"Poor little kid!\" he said.
zh: “可怜的孩子!”他说。

en: \"There is nobody left to come.\"
zh: “没有人会来了”

en: It was in that strange and sudden way that Mary found out that she had neither father nor mother left;
zh: 就在这种奇怪而突然的方式中，玛丽发现她既没有父亲也没有母亲;

en: that they had died and been carried away in the night, and that the few native servants who had not died also had left the house as quickly as they could get out of it, none of them even remembering that there was a Missie Sahib.
zh: 他们已经死了，在夜里被抬走了，几个没有死的本地仆人也已经尽快离开了房子，他们甚至都不记得有一个 Missie Sahib。

en: That was why the place was so quiet.
zh: 所以这里才这么安静。

en: It was true that there was no one in the bungalow but herself and the little rustling snake.
zh: 的确，平房里除了她自己和那条沙沙作响的小蛇，没有别人。
